newsitem.title: USA: Brady debt ambles higher as Russia roadshow ends.
newsitem.headline: Brady debt ambles higher as Russia roadshow ends.

text.p: Emerging market debt prices firmed slightly on the back of a firmer U.S. Treasury market as players marked time before the launch of Russia's long-anticipated inaugural Eurobond, traders said.
"People were just not really involved today," one Brady bond trader said. "Everything is responding to the Treasury market strength. It's very quiet."
In late afternoon trade, Argentine FRBs inched up 1/8 to a bid price of 84-3/4, and Brazilian Cs slipped 1/8 to 71-5/8, while the benchmark U.S. T-bond rose 11/32 to yield 6.41 percent.
Brady bond dealers described the market as relatively slow, but maintaining a healthy tone as Treasuries gained.

"We're still in a phase where you are in cautious mode where you're trying to protect your gains for year-end," said Olivier Lemaigre, debt strategist at Citicorp Securities. "The fact that it's staying at these levels and consolidating higher is rather positive."
The Russian roadshow continued to captivate the market, even though smaller numbers of investors than expected attended the presentation, sources said.
Analysts said the issue, for which JP Morgan and SBC Warburg acted as lead managers, was more likely to appeal to banks and retail investors than to major institutional houses.
The market firmly expected the issue to be successful, and to price as early as Thursday, but what spread would emerge from these extensive roadshows remained open to question.
Most observers expected the issue to prise between 300 and 350 basis points over comparable U.S. Treasuries, and the size to expand to about $750 million from $500 million.
"I would say it will be in the low end of the range," one emerging market analyst said. "They ought to have no problem placing that."

But another analyst suggested that a price of 300 basis points might be pushing the market too hard. "I think there was resistance from some investors at 300-325 and amount being raised to $750 million."
Ahead of the launch, Russian debt gave back some of its recent gains, as Russian Vnesh dollar loans slipped 1/2 to 79-1/4 bid, while the mark loans slipped 1-1/4 to 82-1/2.
A Russian official reportedly ordered the release of some frozen MinFin bonds, and the paper responded positively. MinFin 3s were unchanged at 83-1/8 and MinFin 4s were 1/2 stronger at 60-3/8.
